unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: National Fitness Challenge
question_text:
Two large high schools are competing with each other in a national fitness challenge.
Five students are selected at random from each school. Their running times for a $5\text{ kilometer}$ run, rounded to the nearest minute, is recorded below:
School A: $30, 35, 30, 32, 24$ Mean: $30.2$ Standard Deviation: $4.025$
School B: $27, 22, 36, 30, 31$ Mean: $29.2$ Standard Deviation: $5.167$
Determine the most exact value of a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference of the two schoolsâ€™ running times.
solution:
Use your calculator function for a two-sample $t$-interval, with a confidence level of $0.95$, without pooling the variance. The result will be $(-5.83, 7.83)$.

Note: When the variances are close to equal, one could pool the variances and get an appropriate answer. However, there is no reason to pool the variances when performing the test on your calculator. Clicking "no" on the pooling variances option will always get the appropriate answer.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.

One could alternatively calculate the interval by hand. Use the following formula:

$$(x_1 - x_2) \pm t^{ *} \sqrt{\dfrac{(s_1)^{2}}{n_1} + \dfrac{(s_2)^{2}}{n_2}}$$

The first mean, $x_1$, is $30.20$.
The second mean, $x_2$, is $29.20$.

The first standard deviation, $s_1$, is $4.025$.
The second standard deviation, $s_2$, is $5.167$.

The first sample size, $n$ is $5$, as well as the second sample size.

The $t^*$ using the more conservative degrees of freedom of $n - 1$ of the smaller sample size is $2.776$. One can find this on the $T$ table by finding where $95\%$ confidence meets $4$ degrees of freedom (Degrees of freedom $= n - 1 = 5 - 1 = 4$)

Note: The calculator will get a slightly more precise value. When performing this interval by hand, one should get: $-7.13$ to $9.13$. This answer is quite different than doing it by calculator since it uses $4$ degrees of freedom and a calculator calculates the exact degrees of freedom. However, if one chooses to do the problem by hand, find the selection (a-e) that is the next most precise with the same point estimator of one in this case.
